repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This is the next part of #3689. It removes the long list of defines for all global names pointing them towards the module state objected. Instead they have to be accessed in the module state explicitly.

Current draft to see how much stuff is broken. I suggest this shouldn't go in Cython 3 (even if it works).

comment_data.body:
I don't think we need both a comment and a descriptive name here.
```suggestion
        # If we don't have a funcstate scope assume global scope for now
        if self.funcstate.scope is None or self.funcstate.scope.is_module_scope:
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1946,6 +1957,19 @@ def intern_identifier(self, text):
     def get_cached_constants_writer(self, target=None):
         return self.globalstate.get_cached_constants_writer(target)
 
+    def get_module_state_code(self):
+        # If we don't have a funcstate scope assume global scope for now
+        no_funcstate_scope = self.funcstate.scope is None
+        if no_funcstate_scope or self.funcstate.scope.is_module_scope:

comment_data.body: Given the usage, it feels more helpful to have a method `name_in_module_state(self, cname)` that returns the full `%s->%s` expression. Or maybe `get_module_cname(self, cname)`.

What do you think about handling this in the same way as `PYUNICODE()` etc.? I.e. have a "function" `CGLOBAL(...)` that gets replaced during the utility code loading? It's less to type, more explicit, and easier to change (if needed).

We could also get rid of `Naming.empty_tuple` etc. then and just use `CGLOBAL(empty_tuple)` instead.
This looks surprising. Are you calling the type here?
Using the same name for the type and the argument here seems … funny. You probably did that to avoid renaming the usages, right? It still looks weird, more like a typo at first sight.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1207,7 +1209,8 @@ def initialize_main_c_code(self):
         w = self.parts['cached_constants']
         w.enter_cfunc_scope()
         w.putln("")
-        w.putln("static CYTHON_SMALL_CODE int __Pyx_InitCachedConstants(void) {")
+        w.putln("static CYTHON_SMALL_CODE int __Pyx_InitCachedConstants(%s *%s) {" % (
+            Naming.modulestate_cname, Naming.modulestate_cname))

comment_data.body:
I don't think this option will be the final form here, but it's definitely usable for now.

One thing we'll need to handle in future to support is that in "full" module-state mode, we won't always be able to get the module state (e.g. a `cdef` function has no way of getting the module state). In this case, some things won't be able to work because they just need the module state, but things like empty tuples shouldn't fail because the cached version is just an optimization, and it can easily be recreated.

So the final version will have to be able to cope with that. But I don't think it's worth spending too much time designing around that now.

Yes. Right now `Naming.modulestate_cname` is used for (at least) three different things: a type, a "getter"-functionlike macro, and a value. I'll give all three uses separate names and hopefully it'll be a bit clearer.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1207,7 +1209,8 @@ def initialize_main_c_code(self):
         w = self.parts['cached_constants']
         w.enter_cfunc_scope()
         w.putln("")
-        w.putln("static CYTHON_SMALL_CODE int __Pyx_InitCachedConstants(void) {")
+        w.putln("static CYTHON_SMALL_CODE int __Pyx_InitCachedConstants(%s *%s) {" % (
+            Naming.modulestate_cname, Naming.modulestate_cname))

comment_data.body: I think this is just the "`$modulestate_cname` means 3 things" problem, and will be clearer in the next version. But it might also be a mistake...

I'm not quite sure I understand what this is actually testing, so I'm not sure if this is a valid workaround.

(Also, long-term I think these variables *should* be in the module state so it won't keep working. But that's a "later" problem)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -40,6 +41,10 @@ cdef class TestClass(object):
     def def_cname_method(self, int value):
         print("Hello from def_cname_method", value)
 
+# For now cdef variables are outside the module scope,
+# so we can create a global cname that is easily accessible
+cdef PyObject* __pyx_TestClass_type = <PyObject*>TestClass

comment_data.body: For array indexing, `size_t` seems more appropriate than a signed type, now that we require C99.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1711,21 +1750,18 @@ def generate_object_constant_decls(self):
                 f"Py_VISIT(traverse_module_state->{cname});")
 
         for prefix, count in sorted(self.const_array_counters.items()):
-            # name the struct attribute and the global "define" slightly differently
-            # to avoid the global define getting in the way
-            struct_attr_cname = f"{Naming.pyrex_prefix}_{prefix}"
-            global_cname = f"{Naming.pyrex_prefix}{prefix}"
+            struct_attr_cname = f"{Naming.pyrex_prefix}{prefix}"
             self.parts['module_state'].putln(f"PyObject *{struct_attr_cname}[{count}];")
-            self.parts['module_state_defines'].putln(
-                f"#define {global_cname} {Naming.modulestateglobal_cname}->{struct_attr_cname}")
 
             # The constant tuples/slices that we create can never participate in reference cycles.
             self._generate_module_array_traverse_and_clear(struct_attr_cname, count, may_have_refcycles=False)
 
             cleanup_level = cleanup_level_for_type_prefix(prefix)
             if cleanup_level is not None and cleanup_level <= Options.generate_cleanup_code:
                 part_writer = self.parts['cleanup_globals']
-                part_writer.putln(f"for (Py_ssize_t i=0; i<{count}; ++i) {{ Py_CLEAR({global_cname}[i]); }}")
+                part_writer.putln(
+                    f"for (Py_ssize_t i=0; i<{count}; ++i) "
+                    f"{{ Py_CLEAR({Naming.modulestatevalue_cname}->{struct_attr_cname}[i]); }}")

comment_data.body: Where does this change come from?

comment_data.body:
The mix of "force_global" and "funcstate" seems a bit opaque to me. The comments seem to indicate that you felt likewise.

The normal case should be that we have a funcstate, right? I think that should be visible from the code structure.

What "more choices" do you anticipate here?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2315,6 +2355,30 @@ def intern_identifier(self, text):
     def get_cached_constants_writer(self, target=None):
         return self.globalstate.get_cached_constants_writer(target)
 
+    def name_in_module_state(self, cname, force_global=False):
+        # If we don't have a funcstate scope assume global scope for now
+
+        # default fallback option if we don't know better
+        modulestate_name = Naming.modulestateglobal_cname
+        if not force_global and self.funcstate:
+            if self.funcstate.scope is None or self.funcstate.scope.is_module_scope:
+                modulestate_name = Naming.modulestatevalue_cname
+            # TODO - more choices depending on the type of env

comment_data.body: Can the usage of `code` here be avoided by making the `typeptr_cname` generally absolute?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1649,11 +1649,10 @@ def declaration_code(self, entity_code,
                 entity_code = "*%s" % entity_code
         return self.base_declaration_code(base_code, entity_code)
 
-    def type_test_code(self, py_arg, notnone=False):
-
+    def type_test_code(self, code, py_arg, notnone=False):
         none_check = "((%s) == Py_None)" % py_arg
         type_check = "likely(__Pyx_TypeTest(%s, %s))" % (
-            py_arg, self.typeptr_cname)
+            py_arg, code.name_in_module_state(self.typeptr_cname))

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
            CGLOBAL($moddict_cname),        /*PyObject *globals,*/
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1583,7 +1583,7 @@ __Pyx_Coroutine_get_frame(__pyx_CoroutineObject *self, void *context)
         frame = (PyObject *) PyFrame_New(
             PyThreadState_Get(),            /*PyThreadState *tstate,*/
             (PyCodeObject*) self->gi_code,  /*PyCodeObject *code,*/
-            $moddict_cname,                 /*PyObject *globals,*/
+            CGLOBAL($moddict_cname),                 /*PyObject *globals,*/

comment_data.body:
If we're not using `//@substitute: naming` for this, should we then use a different naming scheme?
E.g. `NAMED_CGLOBAL(moddict_cname)` or `CGLOBAL(Naming.moddict_cname)` ?
I'm not sure it's better, but it seems surprising to see `$name` without `//@substitute: naming`.
Is this something for which we need the `Naming` namespace? We have lots of global helper functions that we just use, why is this different?

It's slightly unfortunate that we don't have a way to hide the lookup details here, like we do with `CGLOBAL()`.
OTOH, what else should this use than a pointer deref? But still, it makes `CGLOBAL()` appear as a leaky abstraction.
Seems unused.

I think this was the only usage of `//@substitute: naming`, so the tag can be removed.
Maybe we could detect that automatically by rejecting utility code in the replacement code if we do not find any substitution? I'll write something up and commit it to master if it works.

The replacements here might also make `//@substitute: naming` useless.
This (again) suggests to me that `CGLOBAL($name)` is confusing.
It looks like non-API types are stored on the module state, so need a -> lookup. The other call to `generate_type_import_call` in this file has `is_api=False` (from the default argument)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -431,7 +431,7 @@ def put_utility_code(name, src_file, include_requires=True):
                 % (Naming.cyversion, entry.name.as_c_string_literal(), cname, sig))

             for entry in api_extension_types:
-                self.generate_type_import_call(entry.type, h_code, import_generator, error_code="goto bad;")
+                self.generate_type_import_call(entry.type, h_code, import_generator, error_code="goto bad;", is_api=True)

comment_data.body:
> The normal case should be that we have a funcstate, right? I think that should be visible from the code structure.

There's definitely a few points in the code generation that we don't. I'll have a look and see if that can be fixed.

> What "more choices" do you anticipate here?

Essentially everything in https://docs.python.org/3.12//howto/isolating-extensions.html - there's future special-cases for module-level functions, methods and slots.

comment_data.body:
The place where funcstate isn't set look to be

```
generate_new_function
generate_traverse_function
generate_clear_function
generate_dealloc_function
```

I think the easiest thing to do in these cases in to add an explicit function `name_in_slot_module_state`.

I'm struggling to refactor this into something better.

Tangentially https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6320 is another case where having `code` in this function could be useful - the string this function generates requires utility code that it can't include itself.

comment_data.body: It's interesting that you sometimes use f-strings and sometimes not. :)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -938,7 +843,31 @@ def _inject_empty_collection_constant(output, matchobj):
     """Replace 'EMPTY(bytes|tuple|...)' by a constant Python identifier cname.
     """
     type_name = matchobj.group(1)
-    return getattr(Naming, f'empty_{type_name}')
+    return "%s->%s" % (
+        Naming.modulestateglobal_cname,
+        getattr(Naming, f'empty_{type_name}'))
+
+
+@add_macro_processor(
+    'NAMED_CGLOBAL',
+    is_module_specific=False,
+    regex=r'NAMED_CGLOBAL\(([^)]+)\)'
+)
+def _inject_named_cglobal(output, matchobj):
+    name = matchobj.group(1).strip()
+    return "%s->%s" % (
+        Naming.modulestateglobal_cname,
+        getattr(Naming, name))
+
+
+@add_macro_processor(
+    'CGLOBAL',
+    is_module_specific=False,
+    regex=r'CGLOBAL\(([^)]+)\)'
+)
+def _inject_cglobal(output, matchobj):
+    name = matchobj.group(1).strip()
+    return f"{Naming.modulestateglobal_cname}->{name}"

comment_data.body:
The two flag arguments don't seem to be used anywhere. I think the `.proto` sections that we want to insert "right here" might not actually be `.proto` sections but impl sections – it's telling that they don't have a separate impl section. If we rename those few, we can get rid of much of this infrastructure and just handle the single impl sections specially when inserting them "right here". Just add a simple method that asserts that all other sections of the utility code are empty, and then process and insert the impl part.

In fact, except for the header file code insertion, all usages of `UtilityCode.load_as_string()` only look at the impl section. So maybe that's a design flaw already that asks for a simpler "get me the formatted impl part" kind of method and then can simply call `code.put()` on that.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2469,6 +2542,13 @@ def put(self, code):
         elif fix_indent:
             self.level += 1
 
+    def put_code_here(self, utility, proto_here=True, impl_here=True):
+        # puts the impl section of the utility code directly to here
+        kwds = {}
+        if proto_here: kwds['proto_writer'] = self
+        if impl_here: kwds['impl_writer'] = self
+        utility.put_code(self.globalstate, **kwds)

comment_data.body:
Assigning this in `generate_result_code()` basically wormholes state between methods, which is always surprising.

The decision only seems to be related to the `entry`, so we should be able to tell at some point during the analysis phase.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2456,12 +2457,16 @@ def calculate_result_code(self):
             return "<error>"  # There was an error earlier
         if self.entry.is_cpp_optional and not self.is_target:
             return "(*%s)" % entry.cname
-        return entry.cname
+        return self.module_state_lookup + entry.cname
 
     def generate_result_code(self, code):
         entry = self.entry
         if entry is None:
             return  # There was an error earlier
+        if entry.scope.is_module_scope and (
+                entry.is_pyglobal or entry.is_cclass_var_entry):
+            # TODO - eventually this should apply to cglobals too
+            self.module_state_lookup = code.name_in_module_state("")

comment_data.body:
This seems to depend on the scope rather than the CodeWriter. Can these helper methods be moved to Symtab.py?

I noticed this when I saw that the type test code generation in `PyrexTypes.py` now needs the code object – just to identify the current scope level.

There's probably an issue with (string/int/…) constants then, but I wonder if constants aren't special enough to break the rules in some way…
It's mostly when I run out of space on the line. `%` formatting is easier to split.

     """Replace 'EMPTY(bytes|tuple|...)' by a constant Python identifier cname.

-    return getattr(Naming, f'empty_{type_name}')
+    return "%s->%s" % (
+        Naming.modulestateglobal_cname,
+        getattr(Naming, f'empty_{type_name}'))
+
+
+@add_macro_processor(
+    'NAMED_CGLOBAL',
+    is_module_specific=False,
+    regex=r'NAMED_CGLOBAL\(([^)]+)\)'
+)
+def _inject_named_cglobal(output, matchobj):
+    name = matchobj.group(1).strip()
+    return "%s->%s" % (
+        Naming.modulestateglobal_cname,
+        getattr(Naming, name))
+
+
+@add_macro_processor(
+    'CGLOBAL',
+    is_module_specific=False,
+    regex=r'CGLOBAL\(([^)]+)\)'
+)
+def _inject_cglobal(output, matchobj):
+    name = matchobj.group(1).strip()
+    return f"{Naming.modulestateglobal_cname}->{name}"

comment_data.body: I've got another PR where I'd like something that puts the impl section *here* are the init section in the normal place. I agree there's no reason for impl and proto though, so I've simplified that bit.

comment_data.body:
> The decision only seems to be related to the `entry`, so we should be able to tell at some point during the analysis phase.

Not sure that's right - it depends on the scope that it's called from rather than the entry. Although I agree it can be moved to the analysis phase.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2456,12 +2457,16 @@ def calculate_result_code(self):
             return "<error>"  # There was an error earlier
         if self.entry.is_cpp_optional and not self.is_target:
             return "(*%s)" % entry.cname
-        return entry.cname
+        return self.module_state_lookup + entry.cname
 
     def generate_result_code(self, code):
         entry = self.entry
         if entry is None:
             return  # There was an error earlier
+        if entry.scope.is_module_scope and (
+                entry.is_pyglobal or entry.is_cclass_var_entry):
+            # TODO - eventually this should apply to cglobals too
+            self.module_state_lookup = code.name_in_module_state("")

comment_data.body: Returning the utility code should fix https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6320
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1504,16 +1504,20 @@ def type_check_function(self, exact=True):
     def isinstance_code(self, arg):
         return '%s(%s)' % (self.type_check_function(exact=False), arg)
 
-    def type_test_code(self, arg, notnone=False, exact=True):
+    def type_test_code(self, scope, arg, notnone=False, exact=True):
+        # returns code_str, utility_code
         type_check = self.type_check_function(exact=exact)
         check = 'likely(%s(%s))' % (type_check, arg)
+        utility_code = UtilityCode.load_cached(
+                    "RaiseUnexpectedTypeError", "ObjectHandling.c")
         if not notnone:
             check += '||((%s) == Py_None)' % arg
         if self.name == 'basestring':
             name = '(PY_MAJOR_VERSION < 3 ? "basestring" : "str")'
         else:
             name = '"%s"' % self.name
-        return check + ' || __Pyx_RaiseUnexpectedTypeError(%s, %s)' % (name, arg)
+        return (check + ' || __Pyx_RaiseUnexpectedTypeError(%s, %s)' % (name, arg),
+                utility_code)

comment_data.body:
I've moved some of the logic to symtab.

I still think it's easier to access them through the code writer, although that's mostly just avoiding rewriting the same attribute lookups each time.
Should hopefully be gone (at least in ToPyStructUtilityCode)
comment_data.diff_hunk:

     def get_cached_constants_writer(self, target=None):
         return self.globalstate.get_cached_constants_writer(target)
 
+    def name_in_module_state(self, cname):
+        # If we don't have a funcstate scope assume global scope for now
+
+        # default fallback option if we don't know better
+        modulestate_name = Naming.modulestateglobal_cname
+
+        # self.funcstate can be None in a few places, including ToPyStructUtilityCode.
+        # TODO - this will eventually need to be fixed.

comment_data.body: Isn't this just `env`? (Plus, maybe, going up the scope hierarchy until we hit a function or module scope, I guess.)
I think the section just above also qualifies for this.

comment_data.body:
What do you think about merging these into one?
```suggestion
@add_macro_processor(
    'CGLOBAL',  # 'NAMED_CGLOBAL',  # first is part of second and thus not needed
    is_module_specific=False,
    regex=r'(NAMED_)?CGLOBAL\(([^)]+)\)',
)
def _inject_cglobal(output, matchobj):
    is_named, name = matchobj.groups()
    if is_named:
        name = getattr(Naming, name)
    return f"{Naming.modulestateglobal_cname}->{name}"
```
Also, you could probably use `output` to build the access name, right?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -838,7 +840,31 @@ def _inject_empty_collection_constant(output, matchobj):
     """Replace 'EMPTY(bytes|tuple|...)' by a constant Python identifier cname.
     """
     type_name = matchobj.group(1)
-    return getattr(Naming, f'empty_{type_name}')
+    return "%s->%s" % (
+        Naming.modulestateglobal_cname,
+        getattr(Naming, f'empty_{type_name}'))
+
+
+@add_macro_processor(
+    'NAMED_CGLOBAL',
+    is_module_specific=False,
+    regex=r'NAMED_CGLOBAL\(([^)]+)\)'
+)
+def _inject_named_cglobal(output, matchobj):
+    name = matchobj.group(1).strip()
+    return "%s->%s" % (
+        Naming.modulestateglobal_cname,
+        getattr(Naming, name))
+
+
+@add_macro_processor(
+    'CGLOBAL',
+    is_module_specific=False,
+    regex=r'CGLOBAL\(([^)]+)\)'
+)
+def _inject_cglobal(output, matchobj):
+    name = matchobj.group(1).strip()
+    return f"{Naming.modulestateglobal_cname}->{name}"

comment_data.body: I think we should also use the helper methods in cases like this. We should try not to distribute the knowledge how global names are built and accessed to places that don't strictly need it. (I guess the missing funcstate gets in the way in a few places, though, right?)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1747,21 +1784,18 @@ def generate_object_constant_decls(self):
                 f"Py_VISIT(traverse_module_state->{cname});")
 
         for prefix, count in sorted(self.const_array_counters.items()):
-            # name the struct attribute and the global "define" slightly differently
-            # to avoid the global define getting in the way
-            struct_attr_cname = f"{Naming.pyrex_prefix}_{prefix}"
-            global_cname = f"{Naming.pyrex_prefix}{prefix}"
+            struct_attr_cname = f"{Naming.pyrex_prefix}{prefix}"
             self.parts['module_state'].putln(f"PyObject *{struct_attr_cname}[{count}];")
-            self.parts['module_state_defines'].putln(
-                f"#define {global_cname} {Naming.modulestateglobal_cname}->{struct_attr_cname}")
 
             # The constant tuples/slices that we create can never participate in reference cycles.
             self._generate_module_array_traverse_and_clear(struct_attr_cname, count, may_have_refcycles=False)
 
             cleanup_level = cleanup_level_for_type_prefix(prefix)
             if cleanup_level is not None and cleanup_level <= Options.generate_cleanup_code:
                 part_writer = self.parts['cleanup_globals']
-                part_writer.putln(f"for (Py_ssize_t i=0; i<{count}; ++i) {{ Py_CLEAR({global_cname}[i]); }}")
+                part_writer.putln(
+                    f"for (size_t i=0; i<{count}; ++i) "
+                    f"{{ Py_CLEAR({Naming.modulestatevalue_cname}->{struct_attr_cname}[i]); }}")

comment_data.body:
I'll annotate them. 

writer is a Code.CCodeWriter
output is a Code.GlobalState

These names are used elsewhere for the same types, so they aren't really my invention.

`output` is needed for `process_utility_ccode` so as far as I can tell they are both needed, much as it makes the signature a bit awkward.

comment_data.body: I don't think it's too late. The tests that fail due to this seem to be mostly fused types and memory view tests, i.e. those for which we generate Cython utility code. My guess is that end up with a the Cython utility scope here and that the utility code that it uses doesn't get passed on to the module scope.

milestone.description:
* Remove code for Python 2 and Python < 3.7.
* Integrate better with Python 3.
* Improve support for the Limited API.
* Start supporting GIL-free Python 3.13.
* Support the Py3.13 `sys.monitoring` API.
* Support and use `am_send` for coroutines.

title: Modulestate refactor
